question_text: Explain the physical mechanisms through which simultaneous surface growth and aggregation lead to the observed sphericity of primary particles and overlapping/necking in soot aggregates, including the role of characteristic time scales.
standard_answer: The simultaneous processes of surface growth and aggregation create a complex interplay that shapes primary particle morphology through competing time scales. Surface growth deposits carbonaceous material uniformly on existing surfaces, tending to sphericalize particles by filling surface irregularities and reducing surface energy. However, aggregation brings particles into contact, creating non-spherical junctions. The observed high sphericity emerges when the characteristic time for surface growth (τ_growth) is comparable to or shorter than the characteristic aggregation time (τ_agg). This allows surface deposition to 'heal' the deformation caused by particle contact before permanent aggregation occurs. Overlapping and necking develop when particles remain in contact during surface growth, where deposited material bridges the gap between primary particles. The degree of overlapping is governed by the ratio τ_sinter/τ_growth, where τ_sinter is the characteristic sintering time. When surface growth occurs rapidly relative to particle rearrangement, material accumulates at contact points, creating neck regions. This mechanism explains why soot primary particles maintain high sphericity despite aggregation - the continuous surface deposition counteracts the shape distortion that would otherwise occur from particle collisions and contact forces.

original_text.2: The overlap/neck between neighboring primary particles in soot aggregates is attributed to particle coagulation in the presence of surface growth.
